content:
re :3. Messages I do not want to see (at that time) are opened uncontrollably, sometimes in large numbers. Apparently related to multiple recipients on a thread. I am wasting a lot of time closing maybe dozens of unwanted messages.

The new default in Thunderbird (set by developers) is to use 'View' > 'Sort by' > 'Threaded' It sounds like you are clicking on a collapsed top level thread.

If you click on the top level thread which is in a collapsed state, that sends the instruction to open all the threads in new tabs. This is not new, but if you have not used 'Threads' before it can seem like an annoyance. You have a choice.

  • Either switch off threading: View > Sort by > Unthreaded
  • OR click on the chevron to expand the thread and then select the individual email you want to open.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
2. The ability to adjust message magnification/font size with Conntrol “+” and “-“ has disappeared. I have to copy message contents into Word now to enlarge enough to read.

The 'Menu app' icon (3 lines) is on the 'Unified toolbar' Click on 'Menu app' icon and you should see 'Font Size' which has the options + and - OR via 'Menu Bar' toolbar - 'View' > 'Font Size' > increase/decrease font size

This option effects all of the UI.

If you only need to increase the font size in the 'Message Pane' then you do it via:

  • Settings > General
  • scroll to 'Language & Appearance'
  • click on 'Advanced' button
  • 'Fonts for' - select 'Latin' (this sets encodings for western)
  • Set 'Proportional - Sans Serf - Size: 16 (try 16 as a start)
  • Set 'Monospace' - Consolas - Size: 16
  • Set 'Minimum font size:' Try 12 (it must not be higher than what is set for the others)

Now you need to set up encodings for 'Unicode'

  • 'Fonts for' - select 'Other Writing Systems' (it's at the bottom of drop down list)

You must set the same as you set up for 'Latin'

  • Set 'Proportional - Sans Serf - Size: 16 (try 16 as a start)
  • Set 'Monospace' - Consolas - Size: 16
  • Set 'Minimum font size:' Try 12 (it must not be higher than what is set for the others)
  • Reselect 'Fonts for' - select 'Latin'
  • Uncheck 'Allow messages to use other fonts'
  • Click on 'OK'
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
Please stop creating new questions on same topic. You have created 6 identical new questions which is completely unnecessary and wastes a lot of time. You need to keep all comments in this question otherwise continuity of conversation is lost. From now onwards please keep all comments in this question. Do not create another new one.

You do not 'Reply' to the email you get. In the email you will see a button that says 'Mark as Solved' and next to it there is some text 'This doesn't solve my problem' - click on the that text as it is a link to this question in Support Forum.

Alternatively - select the question from your profile - I suggest you add the following link to your browser bookmarks just in case you need it: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/user/Jamesrsamec41/questions

You seem to have difficulty uploading images maybe you have not stored the screenshot as a jpg image file - as a heads up Word is a text document file not an image file so you cannot upload it.

How to take a screen shot, save as a jpeg file and upload the image file:

  • Click on the 'prt scr' key on keyboard.
  • Open a simple image program like 'Paint'
  • Use 'Ctrl+V' to paste in the screenshot.
  • SAve as a jpeg file on desktop
  • In this question 'Post a Reply' area add some text explaining image.
  • Below where it says 'Add images' click on 'Browse'
  • locate and select the saved jpeg file
  • click on 'Open'
  • image gets uploaded and then click on 'Post Reply' button.

Post the following information: In Thunderbird

  • Help > Troubleshooting Information
  • Scroll to 'Mail and News Accounts' section
  • Either post an image of that section OR copy all the text and paste it into this forum question.
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Thunderbird is a program you install on your computer, it keeps all it's data on that computer. You said you changed your notebook. What did you do to transfer Thunderbird and it's data to the new notebook.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
If the old computer hard drive was not damaged, and you have someone who can assist, the old profile will be at <drive name>\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles<profilename> and the text file, profiles.ini, that points to the specific profile (assuming there may be more than one) is at <drive name>\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles.ini. The addressbook name is abook.sqlite. If you had a POP account, the account's email messages will be in the folder named Mail\<accountname> in the profile folder. Message folders have two names, such as inbox and inbox.msf. Give all of this information to the tech assistance person and your files can be copied to your current profile using the same same path shown above. For the FUTURE, I suggest periodically creating backups of your PC when Thunderbird is not running. You can do that by - exiting Thunderbird - copying c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to an external drive, such as a USB stick - then, if you ever have to reinstall, the steps are 

  - install thunderbird and exit   - copy the saved backup folder to c:\users\<userid>\appdata\roaming . This will overwrite the default setup       so you will be prompted to allow the overwrite.   - restart thunderbird and your data should be there.
creator: davidsk

content:
It is a folder by folder setting, not a one-time thing. The process is messy, but here it is:

This is the official (to my knowledge) documentation. Well worth the read https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/message-threading-thunderbird

Here is my own documentation on threading, duplicating the above, but it may help: You need to highlight each folder and click View>sort by>unthreaded. If this applies to just a few folders, just repeat the process as necessary. If you have many folders or plan to add many new folders, you may wish a different approach, below:

More info: To change default for *new* folders, In config editor, you can change default that applies to NEW folders you set up: mailnews.default_view_flags 0=unthreaded

Config editor is available at Tools>settings>general and scroll to bottom right. 

 ------------

To set many *existing* folders, follow these steps: (I creates a crude video that walks through the steps. The video was created with table view for the message list pane. 

   https://davidkirk.org/SettingDefaultFolderView.mp4  that demonstrates the following steps: 
   First, highlight a folder that you have set to unthreaded	    In the Message List view, in the column header, on the far right, open the options button that shows         context menu. :    At the very bottom is the option:    -> "Apply current view to..."    -> "Folder and its children..."    -> Hover over an account    -> In the next menu don't select a folder. Instead select the account name itself.  ALSO, for future installations of Thunderbird,  - install Thunderbird and exit prior to setting up accounts - create a simple text file with name of user.js with these lines:       // Set default threading to UNthreaded  ###   <== this line is optional, just for documentation      user_pref("mailnews.default_view_flags", 0); - copy the user.js file into the profile - now, when you start Thunderbird, unthreading will be the default. Problem solved.
creator: davidsk

content:
I don't know for sure what you see as the problem, so I will, instead, explain how it works for me. - I set an alias email id - I send email to a person, using the alias - the person's response comes into my primary email account to which the alias is a managed identity. - when I click 'reply', the alias is shown as the sender, not my primary email address.

That is, when a message arrives into an account, Thunderbird remembers that the message was sent to an alias and uses that by default on responses to the other party.
creator: davidsk

The other two accounts have no additional identities and neither is marked as the default.

content:
I have no idea if the Linux clipboard supports multiple items, or if it offers you a key combination to select a particular item. The Windows clipboard certainly does not.

Perhaps look at this ubuntu discussion of the subject of multiple clipboards https://askubuntu.com/questions/656860/how-to-get-multiple-clipboards or even search for clipboard managers. There are quite a few in the Linux world, you might find one that does what you want.

Your little boxes are called buttons and the ones you describe are on the mail header toolbar. And no they are not really customizable as the toolbar is not user customizable. However Ctrl+P prints.
